position.marginalia_text: Quamcu[m]q[ue] latitudine[m] Planeta vel fixa h[abet] eius quadratus aspectus cadet in ecliptica[e] gradum nonagesimu[m] ab eius loco secundum longitudine[m]. et causa huius est quod ille punctus in ecliptica est instar poli illius circuli p[er] que[m] descripta est stell[a]e lo[n]gitudo, et co[n]tra q[u]ocumq[ue] puncto extra ecliptica[m] accept[o] si p[er] illud describatur circulus mag[nus] (vt su[n]t circuli lo[n]gitudinu[m]) polus eius in ecliptica erit distans 90 gradus ab o[mn]i parte eius circuli, ad angulos rectos

marginalia.translation: Whichever latitude the planet or fixed [star] has, its square aspect falls into the ninteenth degree of the eclipse from its place according to the longitude. And it's cause is that this point in the eclipse is the image of that orbital pole through which the longitude of a star is described, and against, by whichever point [received] beyond the eclipse, if through that its great orbital pole is described (as are the orbits of longitudes) in the eclipse, shall be standing apart 90 degress from every part of its orbit, towards right angles
